Kapilavastu is not far from here. If the ÅšÄkyas know, there may be trouble.
So he took the eight people to the city of Vá¹›ji and stayed under a tree in a grove, expounding the wonderful Dharma for them:

up to the mind is impermanent, dharmas are impermanent, mind-consciousness, mind-contact, and the feeling that arises from mind-contact are impermanent.
You, noble disciples!
You should contemplate in this way, give rise to a mind of disgust, and attain the wisdom of liberation.

When this Dharma was being spoken, the six people exhausted their defilements and attained arhatship.

After King VirÅ«á¸haka attained arhatship, his mind was pure and fearless. Whether sitting under a tree, in the open, or walking, he would always rejoice, saying:

A certain bhiká¹£u, having heard this sound, thought:
Bhiká¹£u VirÅ«á¸haka must be recollecting worldly pleasures and not delighting in the holy life.
He went to tell the Buddha:
Earlier, I heard Vá¹›ji say:

The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

At that time, the World-Honored One, because of Bhadrika, spoke a verse, saying:
How delightful it is for an arhat, no longer bound by affection and love!
Having already destroyed desire, anger, and delusion, there are no more nets of bonds;

The practice of purity is firmly established, without any untrustworthiness;

This is called the lion's roar, with no one able to surpass the Buddha.
Then the World-Honored One, together with the great virtuous disciples, accepted the invitation of Anavatapta Dragon King;
Devadatta had not yet attained spiritual powers and was unable to go, his shame deepening even further. He then thought:

He went to the Buddha and said:

The Buddha then explained it for him. Devadatta received the teachings and during the retreat period attained spiritual powers.
Having attained spiritual powers, he thought:
Who should be transformed first?
He further thought:
King Bimbisara's prince is named Zhongle. I will first transform and guide him, and then the other people will follow my teachings.
Having thought this, he immediately disappeared under the Netra Grove, appeared on the prince's bed, and lay there as a small child sucking his finger.
The prince, seeing this, was greatly alarmed and asked:
Are you a god?
Or a ghost or spirit?

I am Devadatta. Do not be afraid!

If you are Devadatta, then restore your original form.

The prince was delighted and took him as his teacher;ğŸ”½every day he would go out to pay his respects, riding in five hundred carriages. Devadatta would then transform into five hundred small children, lying on their backs sucking their fingers in the carriages.

At that time, the people of the various countries gave rise to a rare thought and said:
Devadatta has great spiritual powers. He created this transformation, causing the prince to go out to pay respects every day and make various kinds of offerings.
Thus Devadatta gradually became conceited and wanted to attract and keep a group of followers.
At that time, the World-Honored One left the Net Grove, traveled among the people, reached the country of Koshala, and stayed in the Ghosita Garden.
At that time, Maudgalyayana stayed in a separate place.
In this country, there was previously a son of Kaundinya named Upagupta, who diligently practiced pure conduct, attained the fruit of non-returner, and was reborn in the Brahma Heaven;
In the quiet middle of the night, he descended from the heavens, emitted a great light, went to where Maudgalyayana was, bowed his head to Maudgalyayana's feet, and said:
Devadatta is now transforming Prince Nanda and displaying various spiritual transformations. I am afraid he will definitely want to attract a group of followers and break the harmonious Sangha.
Having said this, he suddenly disappeared.
Then MaudgalyÄyana, in the morning, put on his robes and went to where the Buddha was. He told the Buddha in detail what KÄÅ›yapa had said.
The Buddha asked MaudgalyÄyana:
What do you think?
Do you think it is really as KÄÅ›yapa said?
He replied:
I think it is so.
The Buddha told MaudgalyÄyana:
Do not say this!
Why is it so?
In the heavens above and the world below, I do not see any Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, devas, mÄras, or BrahmÄ gods who can lead the Buddha's disciples.
He also told MaudgalyÄyana:

There are five kinds of teachers in the world, all of whom are present now:ğŸ”½The first is one whose precepts are impure but who claims to have pure precepts. His disciples know this as it truly is but cover up his faults in the hope of receiving offerings.
The second is one who is deceitful and dishonest but claims to be upright. His disciples also cover it up.
Third, what is said is unwholesome, but they claim it is well-said, and their disciples praise it as good;
Fourth, their views are impure, but they claim they are pure, and their disciples proclaim their views are pure;
Fifth, they expound what is not the Dharma and Vinaya, claiming it is the Dharma and Vinaya, and their disciples also say it is the Dharma.
But they cannot cause the wise to have faith and accept it.
MaudgalyÄyana!

The TathÄgata's precepts are pure, without flattery, his words are not unwholesome, his knowledge and views are pure, and the Dharma he expounds is accepted by the wise. He does not need his disciples to mutually praise and cover for each other.
At that time, there was a bhiká¹£u who had completed the summer retreat in RÄjagá¹›ha. He put on his robe, took his bowl, came to where the Buddha was, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Devadatta has converted the people who enjoy being princes, manifesting as a small child, and even offering various delicacies as offerings.ğŸ”½The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Bhiká¹£us!
Do not envy Devadatta for creating such transformations to gain offerings;
If there are those who respectfully make offerings to him, it will only increase his suffering for a long time.
It is like a vicious dog that is beaten with a stick, which only increases its viciousness.
Devadatta is like this, the more offerings he receives, the more his afflictions increase.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The foolish person increases his evil because of the arising of offerings;
The deluded one severs pure dharmas, just like separating the body and head;
Not cultivating pure practices, yet aspiring to gather disciples,
Desiring to be above the crowd, hoping for everyone to take refuge;
Some people seek offerings, while others seek nirvana,
Offerings harm purity, while tranquility removes stinginess and greed.
He further told the bhiká¹£us:
The banana tree, bamboo, and reed die after fruiting;
Mules also lose their lives when pregnant.
Now Devadatta's greed for profit is also like this.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wanting to elaborate on this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Banana trees die after bearing fruit, and so do bamboos and reeds;
Mules die while giving birth, and scholars perish by themselves due to greed.

Then the World-Honored One, gradually traveling from the country of KoÅ›ala, arrived at RÄjagá¹›ha and stayed at Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain. He was revered, respected, honored, and praised by bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, upÄsikÄs, kings, ministers, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, brahmavÄdins, and householders.

At that time, the World-Honored One was surrounded by an innumerable great assembly and expounding the Dharma. Devadatta then rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, bared his right shoulder, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, knelt with his palms joined, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Please remain at ease!
I will now personally manage the assembly of monks.
The Buddha said to Devadatta:
Even Shariputra and Maudgalyayana cannot lead my disciples, let alone you, foolish one, who eats saliva!
Thereupon, Devadatta gave rise to a mind of anger and resentment:
How could the World-Honored One, in front of the great assembly, scold and humiliate me in such a lowly manner?
Because he gave rise to an evil mind towards the Buddha, he lost his spiritual powers for the first time.
He further thought:
The Buddha praises Shariputra and Maudgalyayana, while disparaging me!
He again gave rise to an evil mind towards Shariputra and Maudgalyayana, which was the second time he lost his spiritual powers.

Long ago, there was a mÄá¹‡ava who was reciting the ká¹£atriya scriptures in a mountain cave.

Having had this thought, he then arose and roamed around, encountering a weak and emaciated wild fox, and wanted to kill it.
The other said:
'Why do you want to kill me?'
He replied:
'I am the king of beasts. You do not submit to me, and that is why I want to kill you.'
The other said:
'Please do not kill me, I will follow you.'
Then the two foxes went wandering together.
They encountered another fox and again wanted to kill it, asking and answering as above, also saying:
'Follow.'

In this way, they gradually subdued all the foxes, then used the group of foxes to subdue all the elephants, then used the group of elephants to subdue all the tigers, and then used the group of tigers to subdue all the lions, and finally managed to become the king of beasts by skillful means.

'Why are you doing this, all you beasts?'

They replied just as they had been told. The king gathered his ministers to discuss this, and all agreed, except for one minister, who said:
We should give her.
Why is that?
What the country relies on is only the elephants and horses;

I have elephants and horses, but they have lions. When the elephants and horses smell the lions, they will be frightened and lie down on the ground. In the battle, we will certainly be defeated and destroyed by the beasts.

At that time, a great minister who was wise and far-sighted said to the king:

The king then asked:

Requesting that the lion fight first and roar later.

The wild fox was arrogant and conceited, wanting to seek his own retinue,
He went to the city of Kashi and proclaimed himself the king of beasts.

In the country of Magadha, claiming to be the lord of the Dharma.

Bhiká¹£us!

Venerable Sangha, listen!
Now we appoint ÅšÄriputra to go to Devadatta's assembly and say:

This matter is settled thus.
Then ÅšÄriputra went to Devadatta's assembly and loudly announced:

Because the Buddha's assembly is pure and free from hatred.
Then Devadatta said to the people:
Do you want to see the maná¸ala flowers in the heavens?
They all said:
We want to see.
Devadatta then disappeared from the assembly and arrived at the flower pond. Just as he was about to pick the flowers, he lost his spiritual powers and returned to his original seat.
Since Devadatta had lost his spiritual powers, he gave rise to evil thoughts and wanted to harm the Buddha. He said to the crown prince:
Now your father, the king, rules the world with true Dharma. As I see it, his decline and demise are imminent.
Human life is impermanent, and the blink of an eye is difficult to guarantee. How can one be sure of a long life and attain the throne?
You should plan it yourself and quickly have the four seas.

Wouldn't it be good if the new king and the new Buddha together spread the teachings in the country of Magadha?
The prince replied:
The kindness of parents surpasses that of the two polarities. They care for and raise me, and I wish to repay their boundless kindness.
How can you now lead me to commit this rebellion?
Devadatta, upon hearing this, had no sense of shame. He still used skillful words to entice the prince's mind;
He eventually became confused and indulged in his words.
Later, the prince secretly carried a sharp sword towards the king's gate. Harboring evil intentions, he trembled in fear. He fell down and got up again in front of the king's gate.
The gate official, upon seeing this, thought:
The prince always comes with dignified demeanor. Today he is like this, there must be a reason.
He then went to ask about it.
The prince replied:
I want to kill the king, that's why I'm like this.
He also asked:
Prince!
Under whose instruction are you?
He replied:
Devadatta.
The gate officials discussed together:
What should we do?
The first suggestion said:
All the monks and the prince's retinue should be killed.
The second suggestion said:
The Buddha has already sent ÅšÄriputra to proclaim his evil rebellion.
How can you indiscriminately kill the monks?
The crime should only be stopped for the prince and Devadatta.
The third suggestion said:
We should not rashly judge this crime, but should report it to the king.
We should follow the king's instructions.
Having discussed this, they reported it to the king.
The king asked:
What is the intention of your many ministers' discussion?
They then fully answered above.
The king immediately dismissed the first and second advisors from their positions, and promoted the third advisor to a higher rank;
he then ordered the ministers to discuss the matter again. The ministers all said:
The second proposal was considered reasonable, but the king dismissed the minister who proposed it. This shows that the king's sagacious mind cannot bear to do harm.
Since the death penalty has been abolished, we should follow the lower proposal.
The king established the crown prince as the heir to the country, but he harbors this rebellion because he desires to become king quickly. If the throne is ceded to him, his evil will surely cease.
The proposal agreed with the king's mind, so he immediately abdicated and enthroned him as king, calling him Ajatashatru.
Having just ascended the throne and enjoyed the five desires, the thought of killing his father temporarily subsided;
after a short time, he then killed his father on some pretext.
At that time, King Ajatashatru had a huge vicious elephant. Devadatta secretly went to the elephant trainer and said:

The World-Honored One, the next day at mealtime, put on his robe, took his bowl, and entered the city with his five hundred disciples to beg for food. The elephant trainer had already gotten the elephant drunk. Seeing the Buddha from afar, he immediately let it loose.
Those who had faith and joy in the Buddha's teachings, seeing the drunk elephant let loose, all went to tell the Buddha:

No trouble!

All the disciples did not realize they were abandoning the Buddha and left by another road.

The non-Buddhists said:
The power of the elephant-dragon is great, it will surely defeat humans.
The Buddha's disciples said:
The human-dragon's way is venerable, the elephant will surely be subdued.

Then the drunken elephant saw the Buddha coming from afar, shook its ears and trunk, and rushed towards the Buddha.

After the Buddha had subdued the elephant, he spoke a verse, saying:
The drunken elephant, filled with anger, came towards the Heavenly Among Heavens,
The common people all watched, collecting money to bet on the outcome;
Its form was like a great mountain, its strength surpassing that of sixty elephants,
Its roaring sound shook people's hearts, with a single roar it could break through enemy formations.
The powerful god among gods, out of compassion for sentient beings, appeared in the world.
In order to save the evil elephant, he stood in front of it;
The elephant subdued, the multitude saw it and rejoiced, both laypeople and monastics,
Praising the Buddha for subduing the evil elephant, just like the king of lions.
At that time, Devadatta saw this and thought:
Now, I cannot harm the Buddha with this matter. I should seek out a violent person who does not recognize the Buddha and bribe him to go and kill him.
He then searched in the four directions and saw a strong man. He said to him:
You kill the Buddha for me, and I will richly reward you.
The man greedily accepted the money and left.
At that time, the World-Honored One was walking in the open air. From afar, he saw that person and filled his body with the samadhi of loving-kindness. He raised his hand and called out to him;
Then, the person unconsciously dropped his sword and quickly went to the Buddha. He bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and said to the Buddha:
I was foolish and crazy, wanting to harm the World-Honored One.
I know my transgression is grave, please allow me to repent!
The Buddha said:
You were indeed foolish!

He then spoke the Dharma for him, namely the discourses on giving, morality, and rebirth in the heavens, and the benefits of renouncing the household life due to the defilements of the household.
The man was delighted within, and the Buddha, knowing his thoughts, further spoke the Dharma for him, namely the discourses on suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
Having heard the Dharma, he was enlightened and, regarding all dharmas, was free from defilements and impurities, and attained the purity of the Dharma eye.
Having seen the Dharma and attained the fruit, he took refuge in the Three Jewels and upheld the five precepts.
The World-Honored One dismissed him, and he returned by a different route.
Devadatta again hired two people to kill the previous person in order to silence the bad reputation;
He then sent four more people, and so on in turn, up to thirty-two people, all of whom went to where the Buddha was.
The Buddha also spoke the Dharma in sequence as before, and they all attained the fruit of stream-entry.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard that Devadatta had sent people to harm the Buddha, and they all held weapons to guard the World-Honored One, dividing up and standing in various places.
It is the constant practice of the buddhas to leave their rooms twice a day. In the morning, he came out and saw the bhiká¹£us all around him, and asked:
Why are you all here with weapons?
The bhiká¹£us said:
We heard that Devadatta sent people to harm the World-Honored One, and we cannot rest easy, so we are here.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
There is no way that the TathÄgata will die an unnatural death.
The five masters in the world need protection!
I do not need you. Each of you go as you please and protect your own minds!
Devadatta, having learned of this, had another thought:

He found a person and went up Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain together.

At that time the World-Honored One was walking on a rock below the mountain. Devadatta then had that person push a rock to harm the Buddha. As that person set out to push the rock, his four limbs could not lift it;
he thought of the Buddha's great merit and virtue, and his hands and feet returned to normal.
When Devadatta saw this, he became even more angry and said:
How weak and incompetent you are! Quickly get lost!
He then himself grabbed a large rock and pushed it down to harm the Buddha.

The World-Honored One, having seen this, said to Devadatta:
You have now obtained the sin of no-interval!

Devadatta then thought:
Since I cannot kill the Buddha, I will only destroy his harmonious Sangha!
If I can destroy the harmonious Sangha of the Buddha with great spiritual powers, my fame will surely spread far.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and said to Devadatta:
Do not destroy the harmonious Sangha!
If one can reconcile the Sangha after it has been broken, that person will be reborn in the heavens and enjoy bliss for an eon;
If one breaks the harmonious Sangha, one will fall into hell and suffer for an eon.
When Devadatta heard this, he temporarily abandoned this thought, but later it arose in him again as before.
The Buddha stopped him as before and then spoke a verse, saying:
The assembly united in harmony is blissful, and harmony always brings peace and security.
If one breaks the harmonious Sangha, one will suffer in hell for an eon;
The assembly united in harmony is blissful, and harmony always brings peace and security.
If one breaks the harmonious Sangha, one will be reborn in the heavens and enjoy bliss for an eon.
If one divides and discriminates, always speaking unwholesome words,
Because of destroying the harmonious Sangha, one suffers in hell for an eon;
If one does not divide and discriminate, always able to speak wholesome dharmas,
Because of harmonizing the broken Sangha, one is born in the heavens for an eon.
When Devadatta heard this, he temporarily abandoned this thought, but later it arose again, and his skillful means surpassed the previous.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard that Devadatta wanted to destroy the harmonious Sangha, so they went and reported it to the Buddha.
The Buddha gathered the assembly of bhiká¹£us because of this matter, and after reproaching Devadatta in various ways from afar, he said to the bhiká¹£us:
You should appoint a bhiká¹£u who is close to Devadatta to go and admonish him, saying:
'You should not destroy the harmonious Sangha, nor should you do things that divide the Sangha;

' If he accepts it, that is good;

if they still do not accept, the Saá¹…gha should go and admonish them.

The monks reproached Devadatta in various ways and then reported this to the Buddha.
The Buddha assembled the Saá¹…gha of monks and reproached Devadatta in various ways from afar, and then told the monks:
For ten reasons, I establish the precepts for the monks. From now on, this precept should be recited like this:
